narratives.question_text: How clearly did the instructor define the topic of study?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: How clearly did the instructor outline the expectation for the course, classroom activity and homework?
comments: The syllabus was clear and relatively consistent. Any changes to the syllabus were conveyed promptly.
The syllabus reflected what was taught.

narratives.question_text: How well were individual class sessions prepared and presented?
comments: All information presented during classroom sessions was supported with very useful examples. However, there could've been a little more variety in the examples. For instance, textbook examples that involve shapes that aren't square or compact for flexure would be more realistic and, thus, more helpful.

Some of the lectures skipped back and forth and were less streamlined and defined. The overall concepts were presented well, but some of the minute detail in steel got lost as we kept flipping back and forth between the appendices, backtracking, or getting off topic with questions.
Mr. Schmidt is obviously still getting his format worked out, but showed improvement over the semester.
Steve jumped around a lot which was a little tricky to follow, but I felt like he really took the time to teach and explain the material which was really great.
The classes got much better as the term went on. It was Steves first time teaching (I think) and I understand that there is a large learning curve.

narratives.question_text: How well did lectures fit within the boundaries of the course?
comments: Sometimes lectures got incredibly sidetracked, again this got better as the term went on.
Workload was clearly defined in the syllabus
The workload is huge. This is appropriate.

A few of the assignments took 3+ hours to complete due to a huge amount if trial and error. I wonder if giving a range of possible sizes to look at would help that, without diminishing the use if the assignment.
the homework seemed reasonable.

narratives.question_text: How available was the instructor for help outside the classroom?
comments: Schmidt and Kate were always ready to answer questions and made themselves readily available.
Steve, Kate, or Ben are more than willing to set up a time to help.

narratives.question_text: How useful were assignments in furthering an understanding of the topic?
comments: The homework really helps understand the material.

narratives.question_text: If tests were given, how fairly did they measure knowledge gained?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: How useful was this course in preparing you for production work?
comments: I've already used the principles of this course many times during production work.
This subject only applies to certain production assignments, but in those situations, the information is immediately useful.
Overall useful, but sometimes things like finding the lightest beam would be much easier in the real world due to actual constraints on material availability.

narratives.question_text: How would you evaluate the instructor's knowledge of the material?
comments: The two instructors demonstrated two different levels of confidence in their own knowledge of the work. This often lead to confusion amongst students.
He's literally writing the book on it.
Ben has a exceptional understanding and Steve has a great grasp on the topic.

narratives.question_text: Please offer additional comments on such topics as: what worked best about the course, suggested improvements, class materials, etc.
comments: It was weird to have a different professor half way through and even though Steve clearly knows the material, we was very nervous at the beginning but steadily became more confident throughout the semester. I do not blame him though because if I were to teach a Sammler class with Ben Sammler sitting there taking notes I would be nervous as well. Frequently our class would nitpick on problems and "what if" situations that he struggled to wrangle the class back onto the planned lesson and as a result occasionally blazed through a lot of topics at the end of the lecture period.
Steve has a great command of the information but would get frequently side tracked by questions. I think presenting the material in its entirety first would have mitigated the confusion.

My only frustration was some of the test grading. I understand the concepts but made some math errors which drastically reduced my grade. I understand how important it is not to make those types of errors while in a real life situation because it affects the safety of people, but it still was frustrating in an academic test setting.
I thought that Ben Sammler's presence was a boon to this class. It seemed as if he helped focus the class and add significant pieces of information.
I think as time goes on Steve will have a way to better focus his lectures.
